Your talking about the "Mosquito" in the UK. It is based on frequencies tha=
t younger ears are still snesitive to but older ears have lost. The concept=
 really isn't mysterious, hearing is like vision it it can become fuzzy and=
 the range smaller as you get older.

Anyway, the mosquito emits a high pit=
ched whine that hurts people below the age of about 19 or 20.

Regards,

Fr=
ank R.

I thin=
k that the children may even be better at hearing the voices.


On Thu, Jan=
 22, 2009 at 1:12 PM, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:

RJ
I thin=
k the answers will vary from individual to individual based on thier belief=
s. As for me personally I grew up surrounded by unexplained events and my p=
arents tried to ignore the things that they couldnt see because if you igno=
re it then it doesnt exist right? But there comes a time when the child gro=
ws up and forms thier own ideas and beliefs. Personally speaking once I rea=
ched adulthood there were many other people who experienced the same things=
 I did in that house so I began to see that there was more to it than just =
a childs imagination.

Most religions are based upon the idea that there is=
 a higher power, that we all have spirits, and that there is something beyo=
nd this life. To say that someone is wrong for belief in ghosts I would hav=
e to say that billions of others are wrong for having belief at all. I dont=
 think bad of a parent who takes their kids off to church every sunday nor =
do I think badly about a parent who spends some time doing ITC. Telling a c=
hild that there is more than what the eye can see, more than what the ears =
can hear, is giving them the basics for growing up with a mind thats open t=
o possibility. What they do with that is up to them individually.

I worry =
more about the kids who grow up with parents who are alchoholics, drug addi=
cts, liars, thieves, abusers, etcetera.. than anyone. 

As for if the effec=
t is positive or negative, I think that has to do with the intent or the ap=
proach taken by each individual whether it be ITC, religion, or life in gen=
eral.

Misty

<P>RJ<BR>I think the answers will vary from individual to individual based on thier beliefs. As for me personally I grew up surrounded by unexplained events and my parents tried to ignore the things that they couldnt see because if you ignore it then it doesnt exist right? But there comes a time when the child grows up and forms thier own ideas and beliefs. Personally speaking once I reached adulthood there were many other people who experienced the same things I did in that house so I began to see that there was more to it than just a childs imagination.<BR><BR>Most religions are based upon the idea that there is a higher power, that we all have spirits, and that there is something beyond this life. To say that someone is wrong for belief in ghosts I would have to say that billions of others are wrong for having belief at all. I dont think bad of a parent who takes their kids off to church every sunday nor do I think badly about a parent who spends some
 time doing ITC. Telling a child that there is more than what the eye can see, more than what the ears can hear, is giving them the basics for growing up with a mind thats open to possibility. What they do with that is up to them individually.<BR><BR>I worry more about the kids who grow up with parents who are alchoholics, drug addicts, liars, thieves, abusers, etcetera.. than anyone. <BR><BR>As for if the effect is positive or negative, I think that has to do with the intent or the approach taken by each individual whether it be ITC, religion, or life in general.<BR><BR>Misty</P>
